text: Artificial intelligence chatbots have made significant inroads into the tourism industry due to their cost-effectiveness and operational efficiency. However, there is a noticeable gap in research concerning the impact of chatbots' emotional expressions on service outcomes. Drawing from the expectancy violations theory, this study explores the influence of chatbot emotional expressions on customer satisfaction through three experiments centered on tourist attraction recommendations. The study reveals that expressing concern for customers can lead to improved customer satisfaction by mitigating expectancy violations. Moreover, factors such as customer goal orientation, the human-like appearance of chatbot avatars, and the nature of the relationship between customers and chatbots can moderate the relationship between emotional expression and expectancy violation. These findings offer valuable insights for optimizing the deployment of chatbots in customer service within the tourism industry.
